Description.val:
This line item funds modifications to the baseline MQ-4C Triton Unmanned Air System (UAS) to deliver the Multi-Intelligence (Multi-INT) configuration. MQ-4C Triton aircraft and ground stations in the Multi-INT configuration are integral to the Navy's Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR) transition plan. Modifications will include sensor, electronics and communication subsystems that provide Triton's Integrated Functional Capability 4, Multi-Intelligence configuration. 

The MQ-4C Triton Unmanned Air Systems (UAS) is integral to recapitalizing the Navy's Maritime Patrol and Reconnaissance Force. The MQ-4C Triton UAS provides a persistent maritime and littoral Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR) data collection and dissemination capability to the fleet, serving as a force multiplier for the Joint Force and Fleet Commander, enhancing situational awareness of the battle space and shortening the sensor-to-shooter kill chain. Teamed with its manned-capability counterpart, the P-8A, Triton will be a key component of the Navy's family of systems to achieve maritime domain awareness. The MQ-4C air vehicle, mission control system, specialized sensors, and communications suite will play a significant role in achieving the Navy's strategic vision for the 21st century. The Triton system as a persistence ISR enabler provides the supported combatant commander and fleet commander with unparalleled situational awareness of the maritime battle space to develop and sustain the common operational tactical picture. The system will also serve as a Fleet response plan enabler with a persistent, global force offering to provide critical trip wire information for intelligence preparation of the environment. Triton will connect to both the Global Information Grid and the Distributed Common Ground System-Navy information backbone to provide the Warfighter with unprecedented levels of battlespace awareness to synchronize actions necessary to maintain maritime Full Spectrum Superiority. Triton's on-station time and range enables unmatched awareness of the maritime battlespace by sustaining the common operational tactical picture (COTP) for Surface Warfare and the Overseas Contingency Operation.

MQ-4C Triton includes an endurance-class UAS that will operate from land-based sites around the world. Unmanned aircraft at each operating location will provide persistent maritime ISR by being airborne 24 hours a day, 7 days a week out to ranges of 2,000 nautical miles. Worldwide access will be achieved by providing coverage to nearly all the world's high-density sea-lanes, littorals and areas of national interest from its operating locations. Triton will leverage the Maritime Patrol and Reconnaissance Forces community to enhance manpower, training and maintenance efficiencies. 

MQ-4C Triton UAS sensors will provide detection, classification, tracking and identification of maritime targets. Sensors to fulfill mission requirements include maritime radar, electro-optical/infrared and Electronic Support Measures systems. Additionally, Triton will have a communications relay capability linking dispersed forces in the theater of operation and serving as a node in the Navy's networked strategy. The MQ-4C Triton UAS will support the Fleet Commander's common operational tactical picture COTP of the battlespace, day and night. The UAS will cue other Navy assets for further situational investigation and/or attack, and will also provide battle damage assessment of the area of interest. Tactical-level data analysis will occur in real-time at shore-based Mission Control Systems via satellite communications. Further intelligence exploitation can be conducted at shore-based sites or aboard Carrier Vessel Nuclear/Landing Helicopter Dock ships.

The aircraft inventory objective for the MQ-4C Triton at the start of FY2019 is projected to be 2 System Development and Demonstration Test aircraft and 2 LRIP aircraft.


MS-C:  4Q FY16
DT&E:  4Q FY12 - 4Q FY20
OT&E:  1Q FY21 - 2Q FY21

Justification.val: FY19 request resources hardware and installation costs to upgrade aircraft and ground stations to the Integrated Functional Capability 4 configuration.

Name.@footnote: Other Support funds government support to aircraft modification, installation, calibration and testing required for acceptance.
Funding for the 4th aircraft installation will be provided in FY20 budget.

Description.val:
The purpose of this OSIP is to upgrade LRIP 1 and LRIP 2 aircraft and ground stations (Main Operating Base (MOB) and Forward Operating Base (FOB)) to the Integrated Functional Capability (IFC) 4 configuration.  The technical components of the IFC 4.0 retrofits for the unmanned aircraft include:  addition of the High Band Chassis (replaces the Aircraft Identification System transponder and Electronic Support Measure), new Low Band Chassis (includes two Radio Frequency Distribution boxes for Band B and C), addition of Signals Intelligence (SIGINT) antennas, new High Gain Common Data Link (CDL) antenna (replaces existing CDL antennas), addition of a Keyed Broad Area Maritime Surveillance Airborne Recorder (K-BAR) (with TS/SCI classification level), new Airborne Mission Processor (replaces existing Advanced Mission Management System), addition of one advanced digital network services router package shaper assembly, addition of one Ruggedized Inmarsat Dedicated Router, addition of a TS high assurance internet protocol encryptor (HAIPE) (replaces existing HAIPE), new TS Voice Radio, and new Cross Domain Solution (CDS), a new design of the Multi-Function Active Sensor radome, CDL radome, and a new Electromagnetic Interference hat radome.
  
The technical components of the IFC 4.0 retrofits for the MOB/FOB include:  addition of a KBAR docking station, addition of SIGINT workstation servers, addition of CDS, and addition of Sensitive Compartmented Information Facility (SCIF) hardware.

Development Status/Major Development Milestones: Multi-Intelligence Early Operational Capability FY 2020 and Triton Initial Operational Capability FY 2021.
